profileText: A Delegate and a Senator from South Carolina; born at "Hobcaw" plantation in Christ Church Parish, near Charleston, S.C., in 1752; completed preparatory studies; studied law and was admitted to the bar; studied in England 1773-1776; joined other Americans in London in 1774 in a petition against the Boston port bill; returned to the United States and served South Carolina in various military and civil capacities during the Revolutionary War; sent with other Americans as a prisoner of the British to St. Augustine 1780-1781; member, State assembly 1782, and of the privy council 1783; Member of the Continental Congress 1783-1785; member, South Carolina house of representatives and served as speaker; elected as a Federalist to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1795, to March 3, 1801; unsuccessful candidate for reelection; served as President pro tempore of the Senate during the Fifth Congress; died in Charleston, S.C., July 17, 1816; interment in the family cemetery at "Hobcaw," in Christ Church Parish, near Charleston, S.C.

researchRecord.name: 1 letter (May 20, 1778) in Washington Irving's Life of George Washington, Volume X, Miscellany, 1764-1805.

In Read family papers, 1788-1869. 99 items. Includes letters between Dr. William J. Read, U.S. Senator Jacob Read, planter T. Harleston Read, and others. Includes material on the protest (1795) in Charleston against the Jay Treaty, South Carolina sympathy for the French and Bonaparte's rising influence, death of George Washington, work at Marine Hospital in Charleston and fever epidemics there, horse racing, sale of rice, and other business concerns. Also correspondence in Grimke papers, 1761-1866.

1776-1812. 31 items. Legal papers, political and business correspondence. Also correspondence regarding real estate in the Read family papers; and correspondence in Ralph Izard papers, 1769-1831, 1952-1955.
